src: La primera forma de transporte que se conoció fue el caminar. El ser humano comenzó a hacerlo en posición erguida dos millones de años atrás con la aparición del Homo Erectus (que quiere decir hombre erguido). Sus predecesores, los Australopithecus, no tenían el hábito de caminar erectos. Si bien se han encontrado rastros de bipedestación en fósiles de Australopitecos de hace 4,2 a 3,9 millones de años, es posible que el Sahelanthropus haya caminado sobre dos patas hace 7 millones de años.
mt: The first form of transportation known was walking.  Humans began doing so in an upright position two million years ago with the appearance of Homo Erectus (which means upright man).  Its predecessors, the Australopithecus, did not have the habit of walking upright.  While traces of bipedalism have been found in fossils of Australopithecus dating back 4.2 to 3.9 million years, it is possible that the Sahelanthropus walked on two legs 7 million years ago.
ref: The first known transportation was walking, humans began walking upright two million years ago with the emergence of Homo Erectus (meaning upright man). Their predecessors, the Australopithecus did not walk upright as habitually. Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2-3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

El ser humano comenzó a hacerlo en posición erguida dos millones de años atrás con la aparición del Homo Erectus (que quiere decir hombre erguido). Sus predecesores, los Australopithecus, no tenían el hábito de caminar erectos. Si bien se han encontrado rastros de bipedestación en fósiles de Australopitecos de hace 4,2 a 3,9 millones de años, es posible que el Sahelanthropus haya caminado sobre dos patas hace 7 millones de años.
mt: The first form of transportation known was walking.  Humans began doing so in an upright position two million years ago with the appearance of Homo Erectus (which means upright man).  Its predecessors, the Australopithecus, did not have the habit of walking upright.  While traces of bipedalism have been found in fossils of Australopithecus dating back 4.2 to 3.9 million years, it is possible that the Sahelanthropus walked on two legs 7 million years ago.
ref: The first known transportation was walking, humans began walking upright two million years ago with the emergence of Homo Erectus (meaning upright man). Their predecessors, the Australopithecus did not walk upright as habitually. Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2-3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

src: Utilizar buques para transportar bienes es un modo mucho más eficaz para trasladar grandes números de personas y bienes por los océanos. Desde siempre, la función de la marina ha sido garantizar que su país conserve la facultad de trasladar a su población y mercancías, a la vez que, interfiere con la capacidad del enemigo para hacer lo propio. La campaña del Atlántico Norte en la Segunda Guerra Mundial ofrece uno de los ejemplos más claros y recientes de ello. Los estadounidenses intentaban trasladar hombres y materiales por el Océano Atlántico con el fin de apoyar a Gran Bretaña. A la vez, la armada alemana, empleando principalmente sumergibles, intentaba anular esta circulación. Si los Aliados no hubiesen tenido éxito, Alemania podría haber tomado el poder en Gran Bretaña, al igual que lo hizo con los demás países europeos.
mt: Using ships to transport goods is a much more effective way to move large numbers of people and goods across the oceans. From the beginning, the role of the navy has been to ensure that its country retains the ability to move its population and merchandise, while at the same time, interfering with the enemy's ability to do the same. The Battle of the Atlantic in World War II offers one of the clearest and most recent examples of this. The Americans were trying to move men and materials across the Atlantic Ocean in order to support Great Britain. At the same time, the German navy, using mainly submarines, was trying to nullify this traffic. If the Allies had not succeeded, Germany could have taken power in Great Britain, just as it did with the other European countries.
ref: Using ships to transport goods is by far the most efficient way to move large amounts of people and goods across oceans. The job of navies has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while at the same time, interfering with your enemy's ability to move his people and goods. One of the most noteworthy recent examples of this was the North Atlantic campaign of WWII. The Americans were trying to move men and materials across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain. At the same time, the German navy, using mainly U-boats, was trying to stop this traffic. Had the Allies failed, Germany probably would have been able to conquer Britain as it had the rest of Europe.

src: La invención de la rueda de radios convirtió a los carros asirios en vehículos más livianos, veloces y mejor preparados para dejar atrás a los soldados y otros carros. Las letales flechas de las ballestas podían penetrar la armadura de los soldados enemigos. Cerca del año 1000 a. C., los asirios incorporaron la caballería por primera vez. Una caballería es una fuerza de combate montada a caballo. En aquel tiempo, todavía no existían las monturas; la caballería asiria batalló sobre los lomos desnudos de los equinos.
mt: The invention of the spoked wheel made Assyrian chariots lighter, faster, and better prepared to leave behind enemy soldiers and other chariots. The deadly arrows of the bow could penetrate the armor of enemy soldiers. Around 1000 B.C., the Assyrians first incorporated cavalry into their forces. A cavalry is a mounted combat force. At that time, there were no mounts; the Assyrian cavalry fought bareback on the backs of horses.
ref: The invention of spoke wheels made Assyrian chariots lighter, faster, and better prepared to outrun soldiers and other chariots. Arrows from their deadly crossbows could penetrate the armor of rival soldiers. About 1000 B.C., the Assyrians introduced the first cavalry. A cavalry is an army that fights on horseback. The saddle had not yet been invented, so the Assyrian cavalry fought on the bare backs of their horses.

src: Los babilonios edificaron para cada uno de sus dioses un templo central considerado su hogar. Las personas llevaban sacrificios para los dioses y los sacerdotes procuraban satisfacer las necesidades de aquellos celebrando ceremonias y festivales. Los templos tienen un patio abierto y a continuación un santuario interno al que solo podían ingresar los sacerdotes. En ocasiones, se edificaban torres especiales con forma piramidal, denominadas zigurats, para que formasen parte de los templos. La parte superior de la torre constituía un santuario especial para su deidad.
mt: The Babylonians built a central temple for each of their gods considered their home. People brought sacrifices to the gods and the priests sought to satisfy the needs of those celebrating ceremonies and festivals. The temples have an open courtyard and then an inner sanctuary to which only the priests could enter. Sometimes, special towers were built in the shape of a pyramid, called ziggurats, to be part of the temples. The top of the tower constituted a special sanctuary for its deity.
ref: The Babylonians built each of their gods a primary temple that was considered the home of the god. People would bring sacrifices to the gods and the priests would try to attend to the needs of the gods through ceremonies and festivals. Each temple had an open temple courtyard and then an inner sanctuary that only the priests could enter. Sometimes special pyramid shaped towers, called ziggurats, were built to be a part of the temples. The top of the tower was special sanctuary for the god.

src: ¡Sí! Uno de los reyes más conocidos del antiguo Egipto en el mundo moderno es el rey Tutankamón, a veces llamado «rey Tut» o «el niño rey». Curiosamente, en la antigüedad no se lo reputaba como de mucha importancia y en la mayoría de las listas de los reyes antiguos no se lo registraba. No obstante, se volvió famoso luego del descubrimiento de su tumba en 1922. Mientras que muchos sepulcros antiguos fueron saqueados, el de Tutankamón permaneció casi intacto. La mayor parte de los objetos que fueron enterrados con Tutankamón se han conservado en buen estado, entre ellos, miles de artefactos elaborados con metales preciosos y piedras exóticas.
mt: Yes! One of the most famous kings of ancient Egypt in the modern world is King Tutankhamun, sometimes called "King Tut" or "the boy king." Interestingly, in ancient times he was not considered to be of much importance and was not listed in most lists of ancient kings. However, he became famous after the discovery of his tomb in 1922. While many ancient tombs were looted, Tutankhamun's remained almost intact. Most of the objects that were buried with Tutankhamun have been preserved in good condition, including thousands of artifacts made of precious metals and exotic stones.
ref: "Yes! King Tutankhamun, sometimes referred to as ""King Tut"" or ""The Boy King"", is one of the most well known ancient Egyptian kings in modern times. Interestingly, he was not considered to be very important in ancient times and was not recorded on most ancient king lists. However, the discovery of his tomb in 1922 made him a celebrity. While many tombs of the past were robbed, this tomb was left virtually undisturbed. Most of the items buried with Tutankhamun have been well preserved, including thousands of artefacts made from precious metals and rare stones."

src: Conocemos a numerosos políticos, hombres de ciencia y artistas griegos. Es probable que la figura más famosa de esta cultura sea Homero, el proverbial poeta no vidente escritor de dos poemas, obras maestras de la literatura griega: la Ilíada y la Odisea. Sófocles y Aristófanes continúan siendo célebres escritores de obras de teatro y sus trabajos se consideran de los mejores de la literatura mundial. Otra figura griega de renombre es Pitágoras, matemático mayormente conocido debido a su famoso teorema acerca de la relación entre los lados de los triángulos rectángulos.
mt: We know many Greek politicians, scientists and artists. The most famous figure of this culture is probably Homer, the proverbial blind poet writer of two poems, masterpieces of Greek literature: the Iliad and the Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes continue to be famous playwrights and their works are considered among the best of world literature. Another famous Greek is Pythagoras, a mathematician mostly known for his famous theorem about the relationship between the sides of right triangles.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: En medio del cálido clima del Oriente Medio, la casa no era de mayor importancia. Las familias hebreas pasaban la mayor parte de su tiempo al aire libre. Las mujeres cocinaban en el patio; las tiendas eran tan solo mostradores que daban a la calle. Las casas se construían con piedra. En la tierra de Canaán no había bosques grandes; por ello, la madera era extremadamente costosa.
mt: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not of great importance. Hebrew families spent most of their time outdoors. Women cooked in the courtyard; shops were simply counters that faced the street. Houses were built of stone. In the land of Canaan there were no large forests; therefore, wood was extremely expensive.
ref: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family happened in the open air. Women did the cooking in the yard; stores were just open counters looking into the street. Stone was used for building houses. There were no large forests in the land of Canaan, so wood was extremely expensive.

src: Muy pocos habitantes vivían en Groenlandia. Según las sagas nórdicas, Erik el Rojo fue exiliado de Islandia por homicidio y, durante un viaje que emprendió más hacia el oeste, descubrió la isla y le dio su nombre. Aun así, sin perjuicio de su descubrimiento, las tribus esquimales ya habitaban el lugar para ese entonces. Si bien cada país por separado era «escandinavo», existían marcadas diferencias en relación al pueblo, los monarcas, los hábitos y la historia entre Dinamarca, Suecia, Noruega e Islandia.
mt: Very few people lived in Greenland. According to the Norse sagas, Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder and, during a journey he undertook further west, discovered the island and named it after himself. Nevertheless, despite his discovery, the Inuit tribes already inhabited the place by then. While each country separately was "Scandinavian", there were marked differences in relation to the people, the monarchs, the customs and the history between Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.
ref: Greenland was settled sparsely. In the Norse sagas they say that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when travelling further west, found Greenland and named it Greenland. But regardless of his discovery, Eskimo tribes were already living there at the time. Though each country was 'Scandinavian', there were many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.

src: Si bien la mayoría de esa comida nos resultaría bastante familiar, los romanos comían también ciertos artículos poco convencionales en los banquetes, como jabalíes, pavos reales, caracoles y hasta un tipo de roedor, el lirón. Otra cosa en la que se diferenciaban era que la gente humilde y las mujeres comían sentados en una silla, mientras que los acaudalados disfrutaban de compartir banquetes y echarse de lado mientras comían. No es posible que las recetas de la antigua Roma incluyeran alimentos que llegaron a Europa desde América o Asia siglos después. Verbigracia, no tenían maíz, ni tomates, ni patatas, ni cacao y ningún romano de la antigüedad degustó un pavo alguna vez.
mt: While most of that food would be quite familiar to us, the Romans also ate certain unconventional items at banquets, such as boars, peacocks, snails and even a type of rodent, the dormouse. Another thing in which they differed was that the common people and women ate sitting in a chair, while the wealthy enjoyed sharing banquets and reclining while eating. It is not possible that the recipes of ancient Rome included foods that arrived in Europe from the Americas or Asia centuries later. For example, they did not have corn, tomatoes, potatoes, or cocoa and no Roman of antiquity ever tasted a turkey.
ref: While most of their food would be familiar to us, Romans did have their share of strange or unusual feast items, including wild boar, peacock, snails, and a type of rodent called a dormouse Another difference was that while the poor people and the woman ate their food while sitting in chairs, the rich men liked to have banquets together where they would lounge on their sides while they ate their meals. Ancient Roman meals couldn't have included foods that came to Europe from America or from Asia in later centuries. For instance, they didn't have corn, nor tomatoes, nor potatoes, nor cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted a turkey.

src: Se puede definir a una civilización como una cultura específica de la que forma parte un extenso grupo de personas que viven y trabajan en conjunto; es decir, una sociedad. El término civilización deriva del latín civilis, que quiere decir civil, y se relaciona tanto con la palabra civis, del mismo idioma, que significa ciudadano, como con civitas, que cuyo significado es ciudad o ciudad estado y que, además, determina de algún modo el tamaño de la sociedad. Las ciudades estado son las precursoras de las naciones. Una cultura de civilización conlleva una prolongada transmisión generacional de conocimiento, un legado cultural duradero y una propagación homogénea. Las culturas minoritarias suelen desaparecer sin dejar rastros históricos relevantes, y no logran ser reconocidas como civilizaciones propiamente dichas.
mt: A civilization can be defined as a specific culture of which a large group of people live and work together; that is, a society. The term civilization derives from the Latin civilis, which means civil, and is related to the word civis, of the same language, which means citizen, as well as civitas, which means city or city state and which, in some way, determines the size of the society. City states are the precursors of nations. A civilization culture entails a prolonged generational transmission of knowledge, a lasting cultural legacy and a homogeneous propagation. Minor cultures usually disappear without leaving relevant historical traces, and are not recognized as proper civilizations.
ref: A civilization is a singular culture shared by a significant large group of people who live and work co-operatively, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin civilis, meaning civil, related to the Latin civis, meaning citizen, and civitas, meaning city or city-state, and that also somehow defines the size of the society. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

src: El Drukgyal Dzong es una fortificación y monasterio budista deteriorado que se encuentra al norte del distrito de Paro, en Phondey Village. Según cuenta la historia, en 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel construyó la fortificación con el propósito de conmemorar su triunfo contra el ejército tibetano-mongol. El retrato de Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal es una de las pocas reliquias que han quedado del Drukgyal Dzong, como consecuencia de un incendio ocurrido en 1951. Luego del incendio, se preservó y se dio protección a la fortaleza, que mantiene su lugar como una de las atracciones más formidables de Bután.
mt: Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery located north of the Paro district, in Phondey Village. According to legend, in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel built the fortress to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan-Mongol army. The portrait of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal is one of the few relics remaining from Drukgyal Dzong, as a result of a fire in 1951. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, which maintains its place as one of the most formidable attractions of Bhutan.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: EL Reino de Camboya quedó acorralado entre dos poderosos vecinos durante el siglo XVIII. Ellos eran Tailandia y Vietnam. Durante el siglo XVIII Camboya sufrió varias invasiones de los tailandeses, quienes, en 1772, destruyeron Phnom Phen. Hacia fines del siglo XVIII, Camboya también sufrió invasiones vietnamitas.
mt: Cambodia was sandwiched between two powerful neighbors during the 18th century. They were Thailand and Vietnam. During the 18th century Cambodia suffered several invasions by the Thais, who in 1772 destroyed Phnom Penh. By the end of the 18th century, Cambodia also suffered Vietnamese invasions.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: La historia de Taiwán data del siglo XV, cuando los marineros de Europa que navegaban por el lugar registraron el nombre de la isla como Ilha Formosa, esto es, isla hermosa. El establecimiento, en 1624, por la Compañía Holandesa de las Indias Orientales, de una base en el suroeste taiwanés, dio inicio a una transformación en el método aborigen de producción de granos, con el empleo de mano de obra china para trabajar en sus plantaciones de arroz y azúcar. El ejército de la dinastía Qing (1644-1912) tomó el control de la región litoral nórdica y occidental de Taiwán en 1683 y declaró a esta última como provincia dependiente del Imperio Qing en 1885. En 1895, luego de haber sido vencida durante la Primera Guerra Sino-japonesa, (1894-1895), el gobierno de Qing adhiere al tratado de Shimonoseki, a través del cual cede la soberanía de Taiwán a Japón, quien conserva su control sobre la isla hasta 1945.
mt: The history of Taiwan dates back to the 15th century, when European sailors who were navigating the area recorded the name of the island as Ilha Formosa, that is, beautiful island. The establishment, in 1624, by the Dutch East India Company, of a base in southwestern Taiwan, began a transformation in the aboriginal method of grain production, with the use of Chinese labor to work in their rice and sugar plantations. The army of the Qing dynasty (1644-1912) took control of the northern and western coastal regions of Taiwan in 1683 and declared Taiwan as a dependent province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after having been defeated during the First Sino-Japanese War, (1894-1895), the government of Qing agrees to the Treaty of Shimonoseki, through which it cedes sovereignty of Taiwan to Japan, who retains control over the island until 1945.
ref: Taiwan beginning start way back in 15th century where European sailors passing by record the island’s name as Ilha Formosa, or beautiful island. In 1624,Dutch East India Company establishes a base in southwestern Taiwan, initiating a transformation in aboriginal grain production practices and employing Chinese laborers to work on its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces take control of Taiwan’s western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan as a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signs the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it cedes sovereignty over Taiwan to Japan, which rules the island until 1945.

src: Esto se denomina pH de una sustancia química. Usted puede elaborar un indicador de pH utilizando jugo de col roja. El color del jugo de repollo se verá alterado en función de cuán ácida o básica (alcalina) sea la sustancia química. El número de iones de hidrógeno (la H en pH) presentes en el producto químico analizado determina su nivel de pH. Los átomos de hidrógeno están formados por un protón y un electrón. Por ello, un ion de hidrógeno es el resultado de despojar a un protón de su electrón.
mt: This is called the pH of a chemical substance. You can make a pH indicator using red cabbage juice. The color of the cabbage juice will change depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical substance is. The number of hydrogen ions (the H in pH) present in the chemical substance being analyzed determines its pH level. Hydrogen atoms are formed by a proton and an electron. Therefore, a hydrogen ion is the result of stripping a proton of its electron.
ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

src: Los leones son los felinos que más socializan y su vida transcurre dentro de grupos de gran tamaño denominados manadas. Las manadas están formadas por uno a tres machos adultos del mismo grupo familiar, unidos con hasta treinta hembras y sus crías. Por lo general, las hembras se relacionan estrechamente entre sí, lo que las hace una gran familia de hermanas e hijas. Las manadas de leones tienen el mismo comportamiento que las de los lobos o los perros, con quienes guardan una sorprendente similitud (a diferencia de los otros grandes felinos) tanto en su conducta como en que son altamente letales para sus presas.
mt: Lions are the most social of the big cats and their lives are spent within large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three adult males from the same pride family, linked with up to thirty females and their cubs. Generally, the females are closely bonded to each other, making them a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides behave similarly to wolf or dog packs, with whom they share a surprising similarity (unlike the other big cats) both in their behavior and in their high lethality to their prey.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: Por debajo, existen felinos de tamaño más moderado que se alimentan de presas medianas, desde conejos hasta antílopes y ciervos. Finalmente, existen muchos felinos pequeños (que incluyen a los gatos domésticos independientes) que se alimentan de especies de poco tamaño que existen en mucha más cantidad, como insectos, roedores, lagartijas y aves. El secreto de su éxito es el concepto de nicho: cada felino tiene una función particular, que evita que compita con otros.
mt: Below, there are smaller cats that feed on medium-sized prey, from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including independent domestic cats) that feed on small species that are more abundant, such as insects, rodents, lizards and birds. The secret of their success is the niche concept: each cat has a particular function, which prevents it from competing with others.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: Los ocelotes disfrutan alimentarse de criaturas pequeñas. En lo posible, cazarán monos, serpientes, roedores y aves. Casi todas sus presas tendrán un tamaño muy inferior al suyo. Los científicos creen que los ocelotes rastrean y encuentran animales para comer (presas) a través del olfato, oliendo el suelo donde han pasado. Tienen muy buena visión nocturna y en lugares oscuros y, además, se desplazan muy sigilosamente. Los ocelotes cazan a sus presas mimetizándose con su entorno y luego se abalanzan sobre ellas.
mt: Ocelots enjoy feeding on small creatures. They will preferentially hunt monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds. Almost all of their prey will be much smaller than themselves. Scientists believe that ocelots track and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing the ground where they have passed. They have very good night vision and in dark places, and they move very stealthily. Ocelots hunt their prey by camouflaging themselves with their environment and then pounce on them.
ref: Ocelots like to eat small animals. They will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all of the animals that the ocelot hunts are far smaller than it is. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing for where they've been on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with night vision, and move very stealthily, too. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings then pouncing on their prey.

src: Atleta integral, el tigre tiene la habilidad de trepar (pero no demasiado bien), nadar, dar extensos saltos y jalar cinco veces más fuerte que una persona robusta. El tigre es del mismo género (Panthera) que los leones, leopardos y jaguares. Estos son los únicos cuatro felinos capaces de emitir rugidos. El del tigre no es un rugido plenamente sonoro como el del león, sino, antes bien, como una oración de palabras dichas a gruñidos y a los gritos.
mt: The tiger is an integral athlete, able to climb (but not very well), swim, leap great distances, and pull five times as hard as a robust person. The tiger is of the same genus (Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These are the only four felids capable of emitting roars. The tiger's roar is not a fully sonorous roar like the lion's, but rather a prayer of words spoken in grunts and shouts.
ref: A well rounded athlete, the tiger can climb (though not well), swim, leap great distances and pull with five times the force of a strong human. The tiger is in the same group (Genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones who can roar. The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

src: Se define a la célula como la más pequeña unidad estructural y funcional que forma un organismo (cosas) vivo. El término célula deriva de la palabra latina cella, que quiere decir «cuarto pequeño». Si examina a un ser vivo bajo un microscopio, advertirá que están compuestos por pequeños cuadrados o esferas. Analizando un corcho con un microscopio, Robert Hooke, un biólogo inglés, observó pequeños cuadrados en su estructura. Se asemejaban a habitaciones. Fue la primera persona que observó células muertas.
mt: A cell is defined as the smallest structural and functional unit of an organism (living things). The term cell derives from the Latin word cella, meaning "small room". If you examine a living thing under a microscope, you will see that they are composed of small squares or spheres. Analyzing a piece of cork under a microscope, Robert Hooke, an English biologist, observed small squares in its structure. They resembled rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells.
ref: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of a living (things) organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella which means small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, a biologist from England, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells

src: Los animales están formados por numerosas células. Ingieren alimentos y los digieren en su interior. La mayoría de ellos puede moverse. Los animales son los únicos que poseen cerebro, pero no todos; las medusas, por ejemplo, no. Los animales pueden ser hallados en cualquier rincón del planeta: cavan en el suelo, nadan en los océanos y vuelan los cielos.
mt: Animals are formed by numerous cells. They ingest food and digest it inside. Most of them can move. Animals are the only ones that have a brain, but not all; jellyfish, for example, don't. Animals can be found in any corner of the planet: they burrow in the ground, swim in the oceans and fly in the sky.
ref: Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.

src: Las plantas generan el oxígeno que las personas respiran y absorben el dióxido de carbono que ellas exhalan (que despiden). El alimento de las plantas se genera con la energía solar, gracias a la fotosíntesis. Además, ellas nos ofrecen sombra. Construimos nuestras casas a partir de las plantas y con ellas también fabricamos ropa. La mayoría de los alimentos que ingerimos son plantas. Sin ellas, los animales no sobrevivirían.
mt: Plants generate the oxygen that people breathe and absorb the carbon dioxide that they exhale (that they expel). The food of plants is generated with solar energy, thanks to photosynthesis. In addition, they offer us shade. We build our houses from plants and with them we also make clothing. Most of the food that we ingest is plants. Without them, animals would not survive.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: Las plantas generan el oxígeno que las personas respiran y absorben el dióxido de carbono que ellas exhalan (que despiden). El alimento de las plantas se genera con la energía solar, gracias a la fotosíntesis. Además, ellas nos ofrecen sombra. Construimos nuestras casas a partir de las plantas y con ellas también fabricamos ropa. La mayoría de los alimentos que ingerimos son plantas. Sin ellas, los animales no sobrevivirían.
mt: Plants generate the oxygen that people breathe and absorb the carbon dioxide that they exhale (that they expel). The food of plants is generated with solar energy, thanks to photosynthesis. In addition, they offer us shade. We build our houses from plants and with them we also make clothing. Most of the food that we ingest is plants. Without them, animals would not survive.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: Cuando un grupo reducido de seres vivos (una población pequeña) se aparta de la principal de la que provienen (por ejemplo, si se desplazan a una cadena montañosa o a un río, o si se trasladan a una isla nueva de modo que no pueden retroceder con facilidad) se encontrarán, con frecuencia, en un ambiente diferente al que solían estar acostumbrados. El nuevo entorno cuenta con distintos recursos y competidores y, por lo tanto, una nueva población necesitará características o adaptaciones diferentes de las que tenía antes para ser un competidor fuerte. No se han producido cambios en la población original, que aún precisan de las mismas adaptaciones que en el pasado. Al pasar el tiempo, a medida que la incipiente población se va adaptando al nuevo entorno, comienza a asemejarse cada vez menos a la otra población. Finalmente, tras miles o, incluso, millones de años, las dos poblaciones lucirán tan distintas que no será posible catalogarlas como de la misma especie. Este proceso recibe el nombre de especiación, que simplemente significa el desarrollo de especies nuevas, y es una consecuencia ineludible y parte fundamental de la evolución.
mt: When a small group of living things (a small population) separates from the main one from which they came (for example, if they move to a mountain range or a river, or if they are moved to a new island so that they cannot easily return) they will often find themselves in a different environment from the one they were used to. The new environment has different resources and competitors and, therefore, a new population will need different characteristics or adaptations from those it had before to be a strong competitor. There have been no changes in the original population, which still needs the same adaptations it had in the past. Over time, as the incipient population adapts to the new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population. Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they cannot be classified as the same species. This process is called speciation, which simply means the development of new species, and is an inevitable and fundamental consequence of evolution.
ref: When a small group of living things (a small population) gets separated from the main population that they came from (like if they move over a mountain range or a river, or if they move to a new island so that they can't easily move back) they will often find themselves in a different environment than they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different features or adaptations to be a strong competitor than what they had needed before. The original population hasn't changed at all, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to their new environment, they start to look less and less like the other population. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the formation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

src: El corazón, que bombea la sangre, es el órgano más importante del sistema circulatorio. La sangre fluye desde el corazón a través de unas vías llamadas arterias y regresa a éste por otras denominadas venas. Los conductos más pequeños de todos reciben el nombre de capilares.
mt: The heart, which pumps blood, is the most important organ of the circulatory system. Blood flows from the heart through vessels called arteries and returns to it through others called veins. The smallest of all conduits are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: Las primeras especies en levantar vuelo fueron los insectos. Esto los ayudó a evadir a sus enemigos más fácilmente y a encontrar alimento y pareja de forma más efectiva. La mayoría de los insectos tiene la ventaja de poder doblar las alas hacia atrás, pegándolas a los lados del cuerpo. Esto les proporciona un abanico más grande de posibles lugares pequeños para ocultarse de los depredadores. Actualmente, los anisópteros y los efemerópteros son los únicos insectos incapaces de doblar sus alas.
mt: The first species to take flight were the insects. This helped them evade their enemies more easily and find food and mates more effectively. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back, sticking them to the sides of the body. This gives them a wider range of possible small places to hide from predators. Currently, the anisopterans and the ephemeropterans are the only insects unable to fold their wings.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: Una gran cantidad de paleontólogos cree que un grupo de dinosaurios sobrevivió y sigue vivo hoy en día. Son los pájaros. Muchas personas no se los representan como dinosaurios, ya que tienen plumas y pueden volar. Sin embargo, hay muchas características en las aves que todavía las asemejan a los dinosaurios. Tienen extremidades escamadas y con garras, ponen huevos y se desplazan sobre sus patas traseras al igual que el T-Rex.
mt: A large number of paleontologists believe a group of dinosaurs survived and is still alive today. They are the birds. Many people don't represent them as dinosaurs, as they have feathers and can fly. However, there are many characteristics in birds that still resemble dinosaurs. They have scaly limbs and claws, lay eggs and move on their hind legs like the T-Rex.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: Con su dentadura, un triceraptops hubiese podido triturar no solo hojas, sino además ramas y raíces muy duras. Según creen algunos científicos, la alimentación del Tricerátops era a base de cícadas, un tipo de planta común en el período Cretácico. Estas plantas se asemejan a una pequeña palmera con una corona de hojas filosas y puntiagudas. El Triceráptors podría haber arrancado las hojas con su robusto cuerno en lugar de comerse el tronco. Otros científicos sostienen que son pocas las probabilidades de que algún dinosaurio se alimentara con estas plantas, dado que son altamente venenosas; no obstante, en la actualidad, el perezoso y otras especies, como el loro (que descienden de los dinosaurios), pueden ingerir hojas o frutos venenosos.
mt: With its teeth, a triceratops could have crushed not only leaves, but also branches and very hard roots. According to some scientists, the diet of the Triceratops was based on cycads, a common type of plant in the Cretaceous period. These plants are similar to a small palm with a crown of sharp-pointed and thorny leaves. The Triceratops could have torn the leaves with its robust horn instead of eating the trunk. Other scientists maintain that the chances are slim that any dinosaur would feed on these plants, since they are highly poisonous; however, in the present, the sloth and other species, such as the parrot (which descend from dinosaurs), can ingest poisonous leaves or fruits.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.

src: El conjunto nacional de fútbol italiano, junto con el seleccionado de Alemania, es el segundo equipo con más triunfos del mundo y obtuvo la Copa Mundial de la FIFA en 2006. Entre los deportes que más se practican están el fútbol, el baloncesto, el voleibol, el waterpolo, la esgrima, el rugby, el ciclismo, el jóquey sobre hielo, el jóquey sobre patines y las carreras d Fórmula 1. Los deportes de invierno cuentan con más popularidad en las zonas de norte, con atletas que participan en torneos internacionales y eventos olímpicos.
mt: The Italian national football team, along with the German national team, is the second most successful team in the world and won the FIFA World Cup in 2006. Among the sports that are most practiced are football, basketball, volleyball, water polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, horse racing on ice, horse racing on skates and Formula 1. Winter sports are more popular in the north, with athletes participating in international tournaments and Olympic events.
ref: Italy's national football, along with German national football team is the second most successful team in the world and were the FIFA World Cup champions in 2006. Popular sports include football, basketball, volleyball, water-polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, roller hockey and F1 motor racing. Winter sports are most popular in the Northern regions, with Italians competing in international games and Olympic events.

src: Si bien Luxemburgo tiene una historia extensa, su independencia no ocurrió sino hasta el año 1839. En el pasado, las partes actuales de Bélgica pertenecían a Luxemburgo, pero, tras la Revolución belga de la década de 1830, se volvieron belgas. Luxemburgo siempre ha intentado mantenerse como un estado neutral; no obstante, Alemania lo invadió en ambas guerras mundiales. Luxemburgo pasó a ser, en 1957, miembro fundador de lo que hoy llamamos Unión Europea.
mt: While Luxembourg has a long history, its independence did not occur until 1839. In the past, the current parts of Belgium belonged to Luxembourg, but, after the Belgian Revolution of the 1830s, they became Belgian. Luxembourg has always tried to remain as a neutral state; however, Germany invaded it in both world wars. Luxembourg became, in 1957, a founding member of what is now called the European Union.
ref: Luxembourg has a long history but its independence dates from 1839. Present-day parts of Belgium were part of Luxembourg in the past but became Belgian after the 1830s Belgian Revolution. Luxembourg has always tried to remain a neutral country but it was occupied in both World War I and World War II by Germany. In 1957 Luxembourg became a founding member of the organization which is today known as the European Union.

src: La Turquía europea (Tracia Oriental o Rumelia, en la península de los Balcanes) comprende el 3 % del país. El territorio de Turquía tiene más de 1600 kilómetros de largo (1000 mi), 800 km de ancho (500 mi) y tiene una forma más o menos rectangular. La superficie de Turquía, incluidos los lagos, abarca 783.562 kilómetros cuadrados, de los cuales 755.688 se encuentran en el suroeste de Asia y 23.764 en Europa. La superficie de Turquía la ubica en el puesto 37 de los países más grandes del globo, con un tamaño similar al de Francia metropolitana y el Reino Unido juntos. Tres de los lados de Turquía están rodados por mares: el oeste, por el Mar Egeo; el norte, por el Mar Negro y el sur, por el Mediterráneo.
mt: European Turkey (Eastern Thrace or Rumelia, in the Balkan Peninsula) comprises 3% of the country. The territory of Turkey is over 1600 kilometers long (1000 mi), 800 km wide (500 mi) and has a roughly rectangular shape. The area of Turkey, including lakes, covers 783.562 square kilometers, of which 755.688 are in southwestern Asia and 23.764 in Europe. The area of Turkey places it in the 37th position among the largest countries in the world, with a size similar to that of metropolitan France and the United Kingdom combined. Three of Turkey's sides are bordered by seas: the west, by the Aegean Sea; the north, by the Black Sea and the south, by the Mediterranean.
ref: European Turkey (eastern Thrace or Rumelia in the Balkan peninsula) includes 3% of the country. The territory of Turkey is more than 1,600 kilometres (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, with a roughly rectangular shape. Turkey's area, including lakes, occupies 783,562 square kilometres (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 sq mi) are in south west Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,174 sq mi) in Europe. Turkey's area makes it the world's 37th-largest country, and is about the size of Metropolitan France and the United Kingdom combined. Turkey is encircled by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.

src: Con aproximadamente 800 habitantes, la Ciudad del Vaticano es el país independiente más pequeño del mundo y el de menor población. El italiano se usa en Ciudad del Vaticano, tanto para redactar su normativa como para emitir sus comunicados oficiales. La lengua que hablan a diario la mayoría de quienes trabajan dentro del estado es también el italiano y el uso del latín queda generalmente reservado para las ceremonias religiosas. La totalidad de los ciudadanos que viven en Ciudad del Vaticano adscriben a la religión católica romana.
mt: With approximately 800 inhabitants, the Vatican City is the world's smallest independent country and the one with the smallest population. Italian is used in Vatican City, both to draft its legislation and to issue its official statements. The language that most people who work within the state speak daily is also Italian and the use of Latin is generally reserved for religious ceremonies. All citizens who live in Vatican City adhere to the Roman Catholic religion.
ref: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population. Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.

src: En la actualidad, las personas usan las computadoras para manipular imágenes y videos. Es posible diseñar animaciones sofisticadas por ordenador, algo que es cada vez más habitual ver tanto en la televisión como en el cine. Con frecuencia, la grabación de música se hace con computadoras sofisticadas a fin de procesar y mezclar sonidos.
mt: Today, people use computers to manipulate images and videos. It is possible to design sophisticated animations on computers, something that is increasingly common to see both on television and in the movies. Often, the recording of music is done with sophisticated computers in order to process and mix sounds.
ref: Computers today are used to manipulate pictures and videos. Sophisticated animations can be constructed on computers, and this kind of animation is increasingly being used in television and films. Music is often recorded using sophisticated computers to process and mix sounds together.

src: Las ciudades de Harappa y Mohenjo-daro tenían inodoros con descarga en casi todas las casas, los que se conectaban con un sistema de desagüe sofisticado. En algunos hogares de las ciudades minoanas de Creta y Santorini, Grecia, se hallaron vestigios de sistemas de alcantarillas. También contaban con sanitarios en el antiguo Egipto, Persia y China. En la civilización romana, los baños públicos tenían retretes y algunos eran compartidos por hombres y mujeres.
mt: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had flush toilets in almost every house, which were connected to a sophisticated sewer system. In some houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini, Greece, traces of sewer systems were found. They also had toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In the Roman civilization, public baths had toilets and some were shared by men and women.
ref: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had a flush toilet in almost every house, attached to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public bath houses where men and women were together in mixed company.

src: La hoja de los patines para hielo modernos cuenta con un filo de dos bordes separados por un espacio cóncavo entre ellos, lo que permite una mejor adherencia al hielo, incluso al estar inclinada. Como la parte inferior de la cuchilla está levemente curvada, al inclinarla hacia un lado o el otro, el borde que queda en contacto con el hielo también se curva. Esto hace que el patinador gire. Cuando los patines se inclinan hacia la derecha, el patinador también gira en esa dirección; si lo hacen hacia la izquierda, girará hacia la izquierda.
mt: Modern ice skates have a blade with two edges separated by a concave space between them, allowing better adhesion to the ice, even when tilted. As the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, tilting it to one side or the other causes the edge that is in contact with the ice to also curve. This causes the skater to turn. When the skates are tilted to the right, the skater also turns in that direction; if they are tilted to the left, they will turn to the left.
ref: The blade on a modern ice skate has a double edge with a concave hollow between them. The two edges allow for a better grasp of the ice, even when tilted. Because the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, as the blade tilts to one side or the other, the edge which is in contact with the ice also curves. This causes the skater to turn. If the skates tilt to the right, the skater turns right, if the skates tilt to the left, the skater turns left.

src: Para recuperar el nivel de energía previo, deben deshacerse de la adicional que recibieron de la luz. Se hace al emitir una pequeña partícula de luz llamada «fotón». Los expertos denominan a este proceso «emisión estimulada de radiación», ya que la luz brillante estimula a los átomos, lo que genera la emisión de un fotón de luz, que es un tipo de radiación. En la imagen que sigue se ilustran átomos que emiten fotones. Claro está, estos son, en verdad, de un tamaño mucho menor que los de la imagen. ¡El tamaño de los fotones es incluso menor que el de la materia que compone los átomos!
mt: To recover the previous energy level, they must get rid of the extra energy they received from the light. They do this by emitting a small particle of light called a "photon". Experts call this process "stimulated emission of radiation", since the bright light stimulates the atoms, causing the emission of a photon of light, which is a type of radiation. In the image that follows, atoms are illustrated emitting photons. Of course, these are, in fact, much smaller than the image. The size of the photons is even smaller than the matter that makes up the atoms!
ref: "To return to their previous energy level, they must get rid of the extra energy they got from the light. They do this by emitting a tiny particle of light called a ""photon"". Scientists call this process ""stimulated emission of radiation"" because the atoms are stimulated by the bright light, causing the emission of a photon of light, and light is a type of radiation. The next picture shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality photons are a lot smaller than those in the picture. Photons are even smaller than the stuff that makes up atoms!"

src: Tras funcionar por cientos de horas, el filamento en el foco eventualmente se quema y esta deja de funcionar. Luego, la bombilla debe cambiarse. Es necesario ser cuidadosos en el reemplazo. Lo primero que se debe hacer con la lámpara es apagar su interruptor o desconectarla. Esto ocurre porque la electricidad que corre hacia el casco en donde se inserta la parte metálica del foco puede causar una descarga eléctrica grave si se toca el interior de ese casco o la base de metal del foco mientras aún está parcialmente en el casco.
mt: After hundreds of hours of operation, the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the bulb stops working. Then, the bulb must be replaced. It is important to be careful in the replacement. The first thing that must be done with the bulb is to turn off its switch or disconnect it. This occurs because the electricity that runs to the shell where the metal part of the bulb is inserted can cause a serious electrical shock if the inside of that shell or the metal base of the bulb is touched while it is still partially in the shell.
ref: After hundreds of hours of operation the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The light bulb then needs replacing. It is necessary to be careful in replacing the light bulb. First, the switch for the light fixture needs to be turned off or the cable disconnected. This is because electricity flowing into the socket where the metallic part of bulb sits can give you a severe electric shock if you touch the inside of the socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partly in the socket.

The first thing that must be done with the bulb is to turn off its switch or disconnect it. ref: After hundreds of hours of operation the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The light bulb then needs replacing. It is necessary to be careful in replacing the light bulb. First, the switch for the light fixture needs to be turned off or the cable disconnected. This is because electricity flowing into the socket where the metallic part of bulb sits can give you a severe electric shock if you touch the inside of the socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partly in the socket.

src: La bomba atómica opera en base al principio de que se requiere energía para conformar un núcleo con gran cantidad de protones y neutrones. Es similar a lo que sucede al rodar un carro pesado en ascenso por una colina. Al dividir el núcleo una vez más, libera parte de esa energía. Los núcleos de algunos átomos son inestables, es decir que tienden a descomponerse con un mínimo o casi ningún empujón.
mt: The atomic bomb operates on the principle that energy is required to form a nucleus with a large number of protons and neutrons. It is similar to what happens when a heavy car rolls up a hill. By splitting the nucleus again, it releases some of that energy. The nuclei of some atoms are unstable, that is, they tend to decompose with a minimum or almost no push.
ref: The fission bomb works on the principle that it takes energy to put together a nucleus with many protons and neutrons. Sort of like rolling a heavy cart up a hill. Splitting the nucleus up again then releases some of that energy. Some atoms have unstable nuclei which means that they tend to break apart with little or no nudging.

src: Cuando uno se comunica con alguien que está a miles de millas de distancia, se está haciendo uso de un satélite. El satélite en el espacio recibe la llamada y, luego, la refleja de vuelta casi de forma instantánea. El satélite fue enviado al espacio a través de un cohete. Los científicos utilizan telescopios en el espacio, dado que la luz de la atmósfera de la Terra distorsiona parte de la luz y vista que tenemos. Se precisa un cohete gigante, de más de 100 pies de altura, para poder llevar un satélite o telescopio al espacio exterior.
mt: When one communicates with someone who is thousands of miles away, one is using a satellite. The satellite in space receives the call and then reflects it back almost instantaneously. The satellite was sent into space through a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space, because the light of the Earth's atmosphere distorts some of the light and view that we have. It takes a giant rocket, more than 100 feet tall, to be able to carry a satellite or telescope into outer space.
ref: When you call someone who is thousands of miles away, you are using a satellite. The satellite in space gets the call and then reflects it back down, almost instantly. The satellite was sent into space by a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth’s atmosphere distorts some of our light and view. It takes a giant rocket over a 100 feet high to put a satellite or telescope in space.

src: El tiempo es algo presente en todo lugar y que tiene efectos en todas nuestras acciones; sin embargo, es difícil comprenderlo. Tanto los eruditos religiosos, como los filosóficos y los científicos han estudiado al tiempo por miles de años. Experimentamos el tiempo como una serie de acontecimientos que pasan desde el futuro a través del presente hacia el pasado. El tiempo es también el modo en el que comparamos la duración (extensión) de los eventos. Es posible para usted mismo marcar el paso del tiempo observando cómo se repite un evento cíclico; esto es, algo que se produce una y otra vez en forma regular.
mt: Time is something present in all places and that has effects on all our actions; however, it is difficult to understand. Both the religious scholars, philosophical and scientific have studied time for thousands of years. We experience time as a series of events that pass from the future through the present to the past. Time is also the way in which we compare the duration (extension) of events. It is possible for you yourself to mark the passage of time by observing how a cyclic event repeats itself; that is, something that happens once and again in a regular form.
ref: Time is something that is all around us, and affects everything we do, yet is difficult to understand. Time has been studied by religious, philosophical, and scientific scholars for thousands of years. We experience time as a series of events passing from the future through the present to the past. Time is also how we compare the duration (length) of events. You can mark the passing of time yourself by observing the repetition of a cyclical event. A cyclical event is something that happens again and again regularly.

src: Es tradición que el futuro sucesor del trono se enliste directamente en el ejército tras finalizar su educación escolar. No obstante, Charles asistió a la universidad en Trinity College, Cambridge. Allí estudió antropología y arqueología y, tiempo después, historia, recibiendo un 2:2 (un título inferior de segunda clase). Charles fue el primer miembro de la familia real británica en obtener un título universitario.
mt: It is tradition that the future heir to the throne enlists directly in the army after finishing school. However, Charles attended university at Trinity College, Cambridge. There he studied anthropology and archaeology and, later, history, receiving a 2:2 (a lower second class degree). Charles was the first member of the British royal family to obtain a university degree.
ref: Traditionally, the heir to the throne would go straight into the military after finishing school. However, Charles went to university at Trinity College, Cambridge where he studied Anthropology and Archaeology, and later History, earning a 2:2 (a lower second class degree). Charles was the first member of the British Royal Family to be awarded a degree.

src: Luego de reconquistar Danelaw, Inglaterra había disfrutado de un prolongado período pacífico. No obstante, en 991, Ethelred luchó contra la flota vikinga más grande desde la de Guthrum, del siglo anterior. Olaf Trygvasson, un noruego con avidez de recuperar su nación del dominio danés, era el líder de la flota. Luego de enfrentar contratiempos militares iniciales, Etelredo logró arribar a un acuerdo con Olaf, quien volvió a Noruega para intentar ganar su reino, con resultados dispares.
mt: After reconquering Danelaw, England had enjoyed a prolonged period of peace. However, in 991, Ethelred fought against the largest Viking fleet since Guthrum's in the previous century. Olaf Trygvasson, a Norwegian with an avidity to recover his nation from Danish rule, was the leader of the fleet. After initial military setbacks, Ethelred managed to reach an agreement with Olaf, who returned to Norway to try to win his kingdom, with mixed results.
ref: England had experienced a long period of peace after the reconquest of the Danelaw. However in 991 Ethelred was faced with a Viking fleet larger than any since Guthrum's a century earlier. This fleet was led by Olaf Trygvasson, a Norwegian with ambitions to reclaim his country from Danish domination. After initial military setbacks, Ethelred was able to agree to terms with Olaf, who returned to Norway to try to gain his kingdom with mixed success.

src: La cultura alemana ejercía una marcada influencia en el norte de Estonia hacia el siglo XV. Algunos monjes de Alemania querían acercar a la gente nativa a Dios, motivo por el cual inventaron el idioma literal estonio. Su base fue el alfabeto alemán y se incorporó un carácter: «Õ/ õ». Con el transcurso del tiempo, muchas palabras tomadas del alemán se fusionaron. Esto marcó el inicio de la iluminación.
mt: German culture had a strong influence on northern Estonia in the 15th century. Some German monks wanted to bring the native people closer to God, so they invented the Estonian language. Its base was the German alphabet and a character was added: «Õ/ õ». Over time, many words taken from German were fused. This marked the beginning of the enlightenment.
ref: "Around the 15th century, northern Estonia was under great cultural influence of Germany. Some German monks wanted to bring God closer to the native people, so they invented the Estonian literal language. It was based on the German alphabet and one character ""Õ/õ"" was added. As time passed, many words that were borrowed from German coalesced. This was the beginning of enlightenment."

src: Se han hecho varias estimaciones acerca del número de hablantes del hindi. Se calcula que está entre el segundo y cuarto idioma que más cantidad de personas hablan en el planeta. La cantidad de hablantes nativos será diferente según se computen o no dialectos que estén muy relacionados entre sí. Distintos cálculos estiman que existen entre 340 y 500 millones de personas que hablan el idioma y hasta 800 millones que pueden entenderlo. Si bien son similares en cuanto al vocabulario, el hindi y el urdu difieren en la forma de escribirse. En las conversaciones de todos los días, los hablantes de los dos idiomas pueden, por lo general, entenderse unos a otros.
mt: There are several estimates of the number of Hindi speakers. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers will be different depending on whether or not closely related dialects are counted. Different calculations estimate that there are between 340 and 500 million people who speak the language and up to 800 million who can understand it. While similar in vocabulary, Hindi and Urdu differ in the way they are written. In everyday conversations, speakers of the two languages can generally understand each other.
ref: There are varying estimates for how many people speak Hindi. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most commonly spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether or not very closely related dialects are counted. Estimates range from 340 million to 500 million speakers, and as many as 800 million people can understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are similar in vocabulary but different in script; in everyday conversations, speakers of both languages can usually understand each other.

src: El alfabeto coreano es el único diseñado en forma deliberada que aún se utiliza a diario popularmente. Se inventó en 1444, durante el reinado de Sejong (1418 a 1450). Sejong fue el monarca número cuatro de la dinastía Joseon y uno de los que ganó mayor respeto. El nombre original que se le dio al alfabeto Hangeul fue Hunmin Jeongeum, que significa «los sonidos adecuados para instruir al pueblo».
mt: The Korean alphabet is the only one designed deliberately that is still used daily by the general public. It was invented in 1444, during the reign of Sejong (1418 to 1450). Sejong was the fourth monarch of the Joseon dynasty and one of the most respected. The original name given to the alphabet was Hunmin Jeongeum, which means "the proper sounds for instructing the people".
ref: "Hangeul is the only purposely invented alphabet in popular daily use. The alphabet was invented in 1444 during the reign of King Sejong (1418 – 1450). King Sejong was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty and is one of the most highly regarded. He originally named the Hangeul alphabet Hunmin Jeongeum, which means ""the correct sounds for the instruction of the people""."

Sejong was the fourth monarch of the Joseon dynasty and one of the most respected. The original name given to the alphabet was Hunmin Jeongeum, which means "the proper sounds for instructing the people".
ref: "Hangeul is the only purposely invented alphabet in popular daily use. The alphabet was invented in 1444 during the reign of King Sejong (1418 – 1450). King Sejong was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty and is one of the most highly regarded. He originally named the Hangeul alphabet Hunmin Jeongeum, which means ""the correct sounds for the instruction of the people""."

src: Existen numerosas teorías sobre cómo llegó a existir el sánscrito. Una de ellas habla de una migración aria desde el oeste hacia la India, que trajo con ellos el idioma. La lengua sánscrita es antigua, comparable al latín hablado en Europa. El primer libro del que se tiene conocimiento fue redactado en sánscrito. Después de la compilación de Upanishads, este idioma sencillamente desapareció, por cuestiones de jerarquía. El sánscrito es un idioma complejo y rico que sirvió como semillero de muchas otras lenguas modernas de la India, así como el latín es fuente de las lenguas europeas, tales como el francés y el español.
mt: There are many theories about how Sanskrit came to exist. One of them speaks of an Aryan migration from the west to India, which brought the language with them. The Sanskrit language is ancient, comparable to Latin spoken in Europe. The first book of which we have knowledge was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of the Upanishads, this language simply disappeared, for reasons of hierarchy. Sanskrit is a complex and rich language that served as a seedbed for many other modern Indian languages, just as Latin is the source of European languages such as French and Spanish.
ref: There are many theories to how Sanskrit came into existence. One of them is about an Aryan migration from the west into India who brought their language with them. Sanskrit is an ancient language and is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The earliest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of Upanishads, Sanskrit just faded due to hierarchy. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served to be the source for many modern Indian languages, just like Latin is the source for European languages like French and Spanish.

src: ¿Qué efecto tendría en mí la gravedad de Io? Si usted se encontrara en la superficie del satélite, su peso sería menor que en la Tierra. Alguien cuyo peso en la Tierra es de 200 libras (90 kg) en Ío pesaría cerca de 36 libras (16 kg). Ello significa, claro está, que su gravedad ejerce menos atracción.
mt: What effect would gravity have on me on Io? If you were on the surface of the satellite, your weight would be less than on Earth. Someone whose weight on Earth is 200 pounds (90 kg) on Io would weigh about 36 pounds (16 kg). This means, of course, that its gravity exerts less attraction.
ref: How would Io's gravity pull on me? If you stood on the surface of Io, you would weigh less than you do on Earth. A person who weighs 200 pounds (90kg) on Earth would weigh about 36 pounds (16kg) on Io. So the gravity, of course, pulls less on you.

src: La superficie de la luna se compone de rocas y polvo y su capa exterior se denomina corteza. La corteza tiene un espesor de unos 70 km en el lado cercano y de 100 km en el lejano. Es más delgada bajo los mares lunares y más gruesa bajo las tierras altas. Es posible que haya más mares en el lado cercano debido a que su corteza es más delgada, lo que facilitó a la lava ascender a la superficie.
mt: The moon's surface is composed of rocks and dust and its outer layer is called the crust. The crust has a thickness of about 70 km on the near side and 100 km on the far side. It is thinner under the lunar seas and thicker under the highlands. There may be more seas on the near side because its crust is thinner, allowing lava to rise to the surface.
ref: The surface of the Moon is made of rocks and dust. The outer layer of the Moon is called the crust. The crust is about 70 km thick on the near side and 100 km thick on the far side. It is thinner under the maria and thicker under the highlands. There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise up to the surface.

src: Muchas personas sueñan con el día en que los humanos viajen a otra estrella y exploren otros mundos. Algunas se preguntan qué hay allí afuera, otras creen que en otros planetas pueden vivir extraterrestres u otras formas de vida. Pero, si esto llegara a ocurrir, probablemente no dure mucho. Las estrellas están tan dispersas que existen billones de kilómetros entre las que son «vecinas». ¿Estarán, quizás, sus bisnietos algún día en la cima de un mundo alienígena haciéndose preguntas acerca de sus viejos antepasados?
mt: Many people dream of the day when humans will travel to another star and explore other worlds. Some wonder what is out there, others believe that on other planets there may be extraterrestrials or other forms of life. But if this were to happen, it probably wouldn't last long. Stars are so far apart that there are billions of kilometers between those that are "neighbors". Will their great-grandchildren someday be on top of an alien world asking questions about their old ancestors?
ref: "Many people dream of the day when humans can travel to another star and explore other worlds, some people wonder what's out there some belive that aliens or other life may live on another plant. But, if this ever does happen probably won't happen for a very long time. The stars are so spread out that there are trillions of miles between stars that are ""neighbors"". Maybe one day, your great grandchildren will be standing atop an alien world wondering about their ancient ancestors?"

src: El Sol no tiene una corteza como la Tierra, sobre la que uno pueda pararse. Está compuesto en su totalidad por gases, fuego y plasma. A medida que pierde proximidad con el sol, el gas se vuelve más ligero. La parte externa que puede observarse al dirigir la vista al sol se llama fotósfera; esto es, «esfera de luz».
mt: The Sun does not have a crust like Earth, on which one can stand. It is composed entirely of gases, fire, and plasma. As it loses proximity to the sun, the gas becomes lighter. The outer part that can be observed by looking at the sun is called the photosphere; that is, "sphere of light".
ref: "The Sun doesn't have a crust like the Earth that you can stand on. The whole Sun is made out of gases, fire, and plasma. The gas becomes thinner as you go farther from the center of the Sun. The outer-part we see when we look at the Sun is called the photosphere, which means ""ball of light""."

src: El Sol no tiene una corteza como la Tierra, sobre la que uno pueda pararse. Está compuesto en su totalidad por gases, fuego y plasma. A medida que pierde proximidad con el sol, el gas se vuelve más ligero. La parte externa que puede observarse al dirigir la vista al sol se llama fotósfera; esto es, «esfera de luz».
mt: The Sun does not have a crust like Earth, on which one can stand. It is composed entirely of gases, fire, and plasma. As it loses proximity to the sun, the gas becomes lighter. The outer part that can be observed by looking at the sun is called the photosphere; that is, "sphere of light".
ref: "The Sun doesn't have a crust like the Earth that you can stand on. The whole Sun is made out of gases, fire, and plasma. The gas becomes thinner as you go farther from the center of the Sun. The outer-part we see when we look at the Sun is called the photosphere, which means ""ball of light""."

src: Cerca de tres mil años después, en 1610, el astrónomo italiano, Galileo Galilei, pudo observar, a través del telescopio, que Venus tenía fases, tal y como las tiene la luna. Las fases se producen porque solo se ilumina la cara de Venus (o de la luna) que mira hacia el sol. Este fenómeno apoyó la teoría copernicana de que los planetas orbitan al sol. Posteriormente, en 1639, Jeremiah Horrocks, un astrónomo oriundo de Inglaterra, logró ver un tránsito de Venus.
mt: 3,000 years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei could observe, through the telescope, that Venus had phases, as the moon does. Phases occur because only the face of Venus (or the moon) that looks at the sun is illuminated. This phenomenon supported the Copernican theory that the planets orbit the sun. Later, in 1639, Jeremiah Horrocks, an English astronomer, managed to see a transit of Venus.
ref: About three thousand years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei used a telescope to observe that Venus has phases, just as the moon does. Phases happen because only the side of Venus (or of the Moon) facing the Sun is lighted. The phases of Venus supported the theory of Copernicus that the planets go around the Sun. Then, a few years later in 1639, an English astronomer named Jeremiah Horrocks observed a transit of Venus.

src: El río Amazonas es el más caudaloso y el segundo más extenso del planeta. Contiene 8 veces más agua que el río que le sigue en tamaño. Además, el Amazonas es el río más ancho del planeta, en algunos puntos con una amplitud de hasta seis millas. Del total del agua proveniente de los ríos del mundo que desemboca en los océanos, el 20 por ciento deriva del Amazonas. El gran Río Amazonas tiene una extensión de 6387 km (3980 millas) y recibe agua de miles de ríos de menor tamaño.
mt: The Amazon River is the largest and second longest river in the world. It contains eight times more water than the river that follows it in size. In addition, the Amazon is the widest river in the world, in some places with a width of up to six miles. Of the total water from the world's rivers that flows into the oceans, 20 percent comes from the Amazon. The great Amazon River has a length of 6387 km (3980 miles) and receives water from thousands of smaller rivers.
ref: The Amazon River is the second longest and the biggest river on Earth. It carries more than 8 times as much water as the second biggest river. The Amazon is also the widest river on Earth, at times six miles wide. A full 20 percent of the water that pours out of the planet's rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon. The main Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles). It collects water from thousands of smaller rivers.
